metadata.case_name: National Steel Works Ltd. v. Respondent (Income Tax Authorities)

facts.text: The appellant, National Steel Works Ltd., Bombay (assessee), carried on the business of a Rolling Mill prior to the partition of the country with factory in territory now in Pakistan.
Assessee was a member of the Steel Rolling Mills Association of India and received quota of coal and steel from Government of India.
After Partition, registered office shifted to Bombay with factory there for rolling mill business.
Assessee continued membership of Association and received quota of coal and steel.
Assessee entered partnership with K.P. Irani (owner of New Era Iron Steel Works factory in Bombay but no quota) on September 29, 1948.
Partnership agreement: Continued so long as quota system in Dominion of India or till expiry of lease; capital subscribed in equal shares.

Clause 12 of 1948 agreement: Partnership to pay Rs. 50/- per ton on all steel received from assessee (Company) via Association or Controller, calculated monthly; after deducting expenses, net profit shared equally.
Clause 13: All quota of steel and coal received by Company to be utilised solely for partnership business, partnership to pay for same.
In 1954, assessee and Irani entered agreement modifying 1948 agreement.
Amendments to clause 12: Royalty reduced - Rs.25/ton from 1/10/1953 to 30/6/1954 on rollable materials except semis/perfect billets at Rs.10/ton; cess to Association paid by partnership.

Irani to pay lump sum Rs.60,000 as goodwill for waiving royalty on quota of re-rollable scrap after 30/6/1954; debited to Irani's capital account at 6% interest from 1/7/1954; no royalty after 30/6/1954; Rs.500/month office allowance from 1/10/1953.
Income-tax Officer assessed Rs.60,000 to tax in assessee's income-tax.
Assessee's appeals to Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Income-tax Appellate Tribunal failed.
Tribunal stated case to Bombay High Court on application by assessee: whether Rs.60,000 received from Irani is revenue receipt liable to tax.
Bombay High Court (judgment dated July 1, 1959, Income-tax Reference No. 58 of 1958) held it was revenue receipt liable to tax.
Assessee obtained certificate of fitness and filed appeal to Supreme Court under s.66A(2) of Indian Income-Tax Act.

legal_issues.text: Whether the sum of Rs.60,000 received by the assessee company from Irani is a revenue receipt and liable to income-tax.

petitioner_arguments.text: The sum of Rs.60,000 was paid by Irani to assessee in view of partnership getting the rights under the quota which assessee possessed, therefore it represented a capital receipt and not revenue receipt.

court_reasoning.text: Rs.60,000 represents capitalised profits of assessee on account of transferring or selling steel purchased under its quota authority; assessee purchases goods in own name and delivers to partnership at cost price.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rs.50/ton under original agreement was profit per ton; Rs.60,000 is capitalised value of future profits on supplying steel at cost; no transfer of quota rights.

court_reasoning.text: Description as 'goodwill' in consideration of waiving royalty conveys no meaning; no question of goodwill in waiving royalty.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court correctly concluded it is revenue receipt.

holdings.text: The sum of Rs.60,000 is a revenue receipt liable to income-tax.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-Tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Provision under which appeal to Supreme Court was filed

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding the High Court's decision that Rs.60,000 received by the assessee is a revenue receipt liable to income-tax.

key_quotes.text: It is clear from the facts stated in the statement of the case that this amount represents capitalised profits of the assessee company on account of its transferring or selling the steel which the assessee company purchased, under the authority given by the quota allowed to it.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning classifying Rs.60,000 as capitalised revenue profits

key_quotes.text: No right, to the quota itself has been transferred to Irani or the partnership under the agreement and therefore there could be no basis for considering that this amount of Rs. 60,000/- was paid in lieu of the transfer of rights in the quota of steel to Irani or the partnership.
key_quotes.speaker: court
